captions.text: [CAR ACCELERATING]

MATT FARAH: As some of you know,
my daily driver is a
Ford Raptor.

Now, some people think that my
Raptor isn't fast enough, that

I need a 600-horsepower
Raptor.

So we've come to Sealy, Texas,
today to talk to John Hennessy
about fast Raptors.

Should my Raptor remain stock
with warranty intact so I can
destroy it at will?

Or should I bring it down here
and spend $16,000 on his
Velociraptor?
Let's find out.

This Raptor is a 2012 model so
there's automatically a few
differences from my truck.
Let's see what they are.

First off, all new
transmission with
manual shift controls.
My truck doesn't get that.

You can automatically
tell this truck
is quite a bit louder.

It's got the long tube headers
and the full length exhaust.

But what you also get is
this little button.

And this little button opens
up the dumps in the exhaust
right before the muffler.

So when I hit Open, you can hear
the valve turning, and
it's now open.
And when I mat it--
[ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: --all hell
fire breaks loose.

And this is now the official
ambassador to mullet America.
So the real question is this.

Why do you want to spend $16,000
on a Velociraptor?

Well, it's dick measuring,
right?

My Raptor has more power
than your Raptor.

It's good to know that when you
do it, there's not a whole
lot of sacrifice.

Once you write the check, you'll
probably get worse fuel

economy, because I'd have
a hard time keeping
my foot out of it.

You'll hit 60 miles an hour
of full second faster.

You'll hit the quarter
mile almost two
seconds faster than stock.

And if you're going to be out
there jumping dunes and racing

your buddies, nice to know that
your Raptor is faster
than his Raptor.
Do I need one?
Probably not.

I spent extra for my
100,000-mile warranty.

And even though John does offer
a warranty with this

truck, I don't want to have to
send my truck to Texas if
something breaks.
I live far away.

John said it makes about 460
horsepower at the wheels,

which translates to about
600 at the crank.
But he has a dyno.

So we're going to head over
there and just make sure.

JOHN HENNESSEY: Where you drive
these trucks is between

And so that's where it's
going to feel torquier.

It's going to feel-- it's
basically going to feel like

the 6,000 pound truck went on a
diet and lost 2,000 pounds.

And that's to me what
it feels like.

So the truck still has the
nimble steering, but you just

squeeze on the gas pedal,
and it just goes.

You don't have to nail down on
it and let it drop down two
gears to take off and go.

The mid-range torque is
a huge improvement.

MATT FARAH: Things like the
off-road mode where that
reprograms the map.

JOHN HENNESSEY: Those
all still--
MATT FARAH: All still work?

JOHN HENNESSEY: The maps all
still work just fine.
MATT FARAH: Oh cool.
JOHN HENNESSEY: Yep.
MATT FARAH: All right.

Let's do a pull and
see what it makes.
JOHN HENNESSEY: All right.
Sounds good.
[ENGINE REVVING]
MATT FARAH: All right.

So what you get here, 463
horsepower at the wheels, 486

pounds of torque
at the wheels.

Now, what's interesting is, on
the speed graph, my truck is

limited to 100, so it would
stop right there.

This one keeps going
all the way to 123.

So it's had the limiter removed,
which is helpful when

you have this much power
to play with.
Now let's go drive one.

I wish I had steering wheel
paddles, but I do get it on
the shifter, so that's OK.

I'm just cruising right now
about 70 miles an hour up the
dirt road, totally composed.

They don't touch
the suspension.

SVT did such a good job
with this truck.

Why would you want
to mess with?
It's just power.

And with a 6.2-liter engine,
it's a big, lazy V8.

It doesn't really ever
feel stressed.

Adding eight pounds of boost
to it is hardly the worst
thing you could do.
Oooh.
Braking.

You do have to remember to slow
down for turns because it
does go particularly quickly.
[ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: You can wake the
dead with this truck.

What I'm not getting is any
supercharger whine.

I know the exhaust is
ridiculously loud.

Let's see if I quiet it down,
maybe I can hear some blower
whine from the TVS2300.
I like this remote system.
It works.

This is about $2,000 if you
want the dump installed.
Now it's quiet.

Still, now it sounds nice and
civil, throaty but not crazy.

But still I'm getting absolutely
nothing from the

supercharger in terms
of whine.

It's just not there, which
I kind of like, actually.

Because this is, at the
end of the day,
sort of a luxury vehicle.

I mean, yeah, it's capable
as any truck has
ever been before it.

But do I want the super
[SQUEAL/WHINE SOUND], the same
way I would with a sports car?
I don't know.

It doesn't work as well with
an automatic transmission.

But in case you're wondering, if
my truck is the best truck
ever, is this one even better?
Yeah, probably.

Just about nothing more fun than
spending your day mudding
in a Hennessey Raptor.

But Zack kept annoying me
about practicality.

ZACK KLAPMAN: You can still
get cigarettes with it.
See, dude, we all still fit.
MATT FARAH: I know.
ZACK KLAPMAN: See, dude.
All this stuff still fits.
MATT FARAH: I told you.

A supercharger doesn't change
the size of the goddamn bed.
I get it.
It's practical, OK?

And when Zack gets the rental
car stuck in a ditch, the

Raptor has no problem
getting it out.

In the end, I kicked him
in the balls and
went back to the dirt.

John Hennessey knows horsepower,
and this thing has
got butt loads of it.
It's ridiculous.

And in case you're wondering,
my average fuel consumption

for this test is indicated at
3.6 miles per gallon, which is
about what I expect.
70, 80 on this dirt road.
It's like nothing.
So why shouldn't you go 120?

Well, there is a reason
you shouldn't go 120.

It's because if you hit
something, you'll probably
bend your frame or worse.

But on the street, in Bull Run,
when we were driving the

Raptor in '09, the 100
mile-an-hour limiter would

come on in the middle of a pass,
making for a much, much
more dangerous pass.

So I'm glad that in this truck
it's raised to 120.
What a good truck.

And for $70,000 out the door,
how are you going to
do better than this?
I don't see it happening.
Good truck.

I came to Texas to find out if
I made the right decision

leaving my Raptor stock and
keeping its warranty intact.

Or if I should have dumped a
lot of money into it with

someone like Hennessey to
go for 600 horsepower of
supercharged redneck awesome.

Honestly, I think I made
the right decision.

But if you meet some Texans and
drive the roads down here,

you'd realize that an X5 M or
a Cayenne Turbo just doesn't
make sense.

In Texas, they do American cars,
and the Velociraptor 600
is the only sane choice.

This thing is bad ass in
every way imaginable.
And it looks great dirty.

I'm sad, though, that I have
to sit here and wash it

because I feel guilty giving
it back to John as
filthy as it is.

So until next time, I'm Matt
Farah, and I'll be cleaning

this thing for the next four
days right here on TUNED.

comments.text: absolutely worthless and useless JUNK﻿
comments.author: hisham jaber

comments.text:
+Chris Chandler If you only want an exhilarating off road experience go a 
modern quad ATV or if you're over the age of 50 choose a side by side ATV. 
 This is still an off road spec'd pickup that sacrifices ability to claim 
able to still tow and haul.  It's split down the middle on both of those 
traits.  I still applaud Ford on their ability to balance those qualities 
and make it marketable.
comments.author: dan buker

comments.text: Defiantly mad because he can't afford one.
comments.author: Giantsasquatch_GamingHD 14

comments.text:
+dan buker The original purpose of the raptor was never trucking hauling or 
towing. It was made for off roading and only off roading. 
We live in an age where you can change the purpose of something on a whim; 
it's beautiful.
comments.author: Chris Chandler

comments.text: your a jealous cheap cunt...lol..
comments.author: trevor cutts

comments.text:
It's much less efficient at the original purpose(trucking, hauling, towing) 
and it costs a ton plus it's kind of inconvenient to load/unload the bed or 
attach to a trailer.  What it does do in trade is accelerate very strong, 
handle off road conditions wonderfully and look menacing.  It's all trade 
offs so people stop getting to pissed off while being narrow minded.  OP 
must not go offroad at the limit often enough like me.
comments.author: dan buker

comments.text: You mad because you can't afford one?
